skill.name: documentation
skill.description: Enforces documentation standards and structure for this project. This skill should be used when creating, updating, or organizing documentation to ensure compliance with project rules, prevent redundancy, and maintain screen-based organization. Activates when user asks to create/update docs or when documentation needs to be generated.

security_audit.summary: All 805 static findings are false positives. The analyzer flagged markdown documentation showing example shell commands and technical keywords as security risks. Actual shell scripts are legitimate documentation utilities using standard Unix tools.

content.value_statement: Managing documentation at scale leads to duplicated content and inconsistent structures. This skill provides section-level editing tools, templates, and workflows to maintain clean, DRY documentation that stays in sync with code.
actual_capabilities: Search documentation without loading full files into context
Extract, update, or delete specific sections by heading
Apply consistent templates for screen, feature, and architecture docs
Validate files against project documentation rules
Split large files exceeding 500 lines into logical sections
limitations: Cannot process binary or non-text file formats
Scripts require bash and standard Unix utilities

use_cases.title: Standardize new documentation
use_cases.description: Apply consistent templates and structure when adding new feature or screen documentation.

use_cases.title: Find and fix duplicates
use_cases.description: Detect redundant content across docs and consolidate into single authoritative sources.

use_cases.title: Maintain documentation at scale
use_cases.description: Enforce size limits, code references, and DRY principles across growing codebases.

prompt_templates.title: Create screen docs
prompt_templates.prompt: Create documentation for the new {screen-name} screen following the project templates. Check for existing docs first.

prompt_templates.title: Update related docs
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all documentation related to {feature-name} and update the affected sections to match the code changes.

prompt_templates.title: Check for duplicates
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for existing documentation about {topic}. If duplicates exist, consolidate them instead of creating new files.

prompt_templates.title: Split large files
prompt_templates.prompt: Check docs/screens/{screen-name}/README.md line count. If over 450 lines, split into focused sub-files.

output_examples.input: Create documentation for a new Settings screen
Find duplicate documentation about user authentication
output: Found duplicate sections in docs/architecture/security.md and docs/guides/auth.md

output_examples.input: Check documentation quality for the Home screen
output: All files pass validation: DRY principle, code references, size limits

best_practices: Always search for existing documentation before creating new files
Use section-level scripts to minimize context usage when making targeted updates
Validate every new or modified file against references/rules.md before committing
anti_patterns: Creating duplicate documentation instead of updating existing files
Leaving files over 500 lines without splitting into focused sub-files
Omitting file:line references when documenting code behavior

faq.question: What file formats does this skill support?
faq.answer: Markdown files (.md) with standard heading structure for section-level operations.

faq.question: How does section-level editing work?
faq.answer: Scripts identify sections by markdown headings (H2, H3) and operate on content blocks between them.

faq.question: What happens if a file exceeds 500 lines?
faq.answer: The skill detects oversized files and recommends splitting into focused sub-files by topic.

faq.question: Can this skill work with documentation outside the docs/ folder?
faq.answer: Yes, scripts accept custom directories as parameters for flexibility.

faq.question: How are duplicates detected?
faq.answer: The doc-find-duplicates.sh script compares file content and section headings for similarity.

faq.question: What tools are required for the scripts?
faq.answer: Standard Unix utilities: grep, find, wc, stat, sed, sort, comm. Available on most systems.
